descriptions: Part of the 'Receipt & Transfers' team, helping move our products from provider to warehouse or from warehouse to warehouse.
Led development of the 'Receipt' API, making sure all compliance regarding products are being met
Ensured sending and receiving of notifications in multiple microservices to keep track and update accordingly the current, reserved and outgoing product stock in warehouses.
Continuously monitored the health of the Reception & Transfers microservice through Grafana and Kibana.
Took some personal time to rest.
Delved into healthy habits and routines to have a more fulfilling life.
Used this time for introspection and re-kindled some passions like overall fitness.
Part of the Load Balancing team of Substrate, balancing the M365 data on servers all around the world.
Continuously worked and improved the “Monitoring Mailboxes” which let monitoring team know if a database was not working as intended or failing.

Shed more light on the “Drain” process (moving data from a server/db to another server/db) used by many teams, giving more visibility, observability and fixing bugs that prevented this process from working correctly
Took charge of checking the proper functioning of drains, by analyzing logs and checking up with customers around the world (freed 50+ petabytes of unused space, saving thousands of dollars).
Continuously monitored the health of the Load Balancing service, specifically in how the monitoring mailboxes were faring through Grafana.
Fixed assorted bugs related to the correct functioning of the Load Balancing Service.
Led the development of the users creation feature of the web portal (database modeling, backend, frontend).
Developed the backend of a mobile app that let sellers from this company access their resources. Partially developed the app itself.
Led the development of a feature that consisted of subscribing users to funeral insurances and letting them pay the subscription through the monthly gas bill.
Co-led development of the backend migration from Ruby on Rails to NodeJS.
